content.text: For the common-collector amplifier in <image 1> find $r_{out}$.

The common-collector amplifier, also known as an emitter follower, has a very low output resistance. The output resistance \( r_{out} \) of a common-collector amplifier can be approximated by the following formula:

\[ r_{out} = \frac{R_E}{\beta + 1} \]

where:
- \( R_E \) is the emitter resistor (5.6 kΩ in this case),
- \( \beta \) is the current gain of the transistor (50 in this case).

Plugging in the values:

\[ r_{out} = \frac{5.6 \text{ kΩ}}{50 + 1} \]
\[ r_{out} = \frac{5.6 \text{ kΩ}}{51} \]
\[ r_{out} \approx 0.11 \text{ kΩ} \]
\[ r_{out} \approx 110 \Omega \]

So, the output resistance \( r_{out} \) of the common-collector amplifier is approximately 110 Ω.

final_answer:
The common-collector amplifier, also known as an emitter follower, has a very low output resistance. The output resistance \( r_{out} \) of a common-collector amplifier can be approximated by the following formula:

\[ r_{out} = \frac{R_E}{\beta + 1} \]

where:
- \( R_E \) is the emitter resistor (5.6 kΩ in this case),
- \( \beta \) is the current gain of the transistor (50 in this case).

Plugging in the values:

\[ r_{out} = \frac{5.6 \text{ kΩ}}{50 + 1} \]
\[ r_{out} = \frac{5.6 \text{ kΩ}}{51} \]
\[ r_{out} \approx 0.11 \text{ kΩ} \]
\[ r_{out} \approx 110 \Omega \]

So, the output resistance \( r_{out} \) of the common-collector amplifier is approximately 110 Ω.
